# Definition of Absolute Value

::: {.callout-note title="ğŸ“– Definition"}
The **absolute value** (or modulus) of a real number \(x\) is defined by:
\[
|x| =
\begin{cases}
 x, & \text{if } x \ge 0, \\
 -x, & \text{if } x < 0.
\end{cases}
\]
:::

---

# Geometric Interpretation
- The modulus represents the **distance from \(x\) to the origin** on the real line.  
- Hence, \(|x|\ge 0\) for all \(x \in \mathbb{R}\).

![](../images/imagem1-modulo1_3.svg){fig-align="center" width="100%" fig-cap="Absolute Value"}

---

# Properties of the Absolute Value

::: {.callout-important title="ğŸ“ Main Properties"}
1. \(|x|\ge 0\) and \(|x|=0 \iff x=0\).  
2. \(|xy|=|x|\cdot|y|\).  
3. \(|\frac{x}{y}|=\frac{|x|}{|y|}\), if \(y\ne0\).  
4. \(|x+y|\le |x|+|y|\) (**triangle inequality**).  
5. \(||x|-|y||\le |x-y|\) (**reverse triangle inequality**).  
6. \(|x|=\max\{x,-x\}=\sqrt{x^2}\).  
:::

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="ğŸ§¾ Proof Sketches"}
- **(1)** By definition, \(|x|\) is the distance to the origin. Distances are never negative and vanish only at the origin (\(x=0\)).  

- **(2)** For \(x,y\in\mathbb{R}\), the sign of a product is the product of the signs, hence  
  \[
  |xy| = (\pm x)\cdot(\pm y) = |x|\cdot |y|.
  \]

- **(3)** For \(y\ne0\), divide the equality from (2):  
  \[
  |x/y| = \frac{|x|}{|y|}.
  \]

- **(4) Triangle inequality.** Geometrically, \(|x+y|\) is the distance from \(0\) to \(x+y\), which cannot exceed the sum of the distances from \(x\) and \(y\) to \(0\). Formally, using \(|xy|\le |x||y|\):  
  \[
  |x+y|^2 = (x+y)^2 = x^2 + 2xy + y^2 \le x^2 + 2|x||y| + y^2 = (|x|+|y|)^2,
  \]
  hence \(|x+y|\le |x|+|y|\).

- **(5) Reverse triangle inequality.** From the triangle inequality, \(|x|=|(x-y)+y|\le |x-y|+|y|\Rightarrow |x|-|y|\le |x-y|\).  
  Swapping \(x\) and \(y\) gives \(|y|-|x|\le |x-y|\).  
  Combining both: \(||x|-|y||\le |x-y|\).  

- **(6) Characterizations of \(|x|\).**  
  By cases, \(|x|=x\) if \(x\ge0\) and \(|x|=-x\) if \(x<0\).  
  Thus \(|x|=\max\{x,-x\}\). Since \(|x|\ge0\) and \(|x|^2=x^2\), we also have \(|x|=\sqrt{x^2}\).  
:::

## ğŸ“Œ Useful equivalences for absolute-value inequalities
If \(a\ge0\), the following hold:

- \(|x|<a \iff -a<x<a\).  
- \(|x|\le a \iff -a\le x\le a\).  
- \(|x|>a \iff x<-a \ \text{or}\ x>a\).  
- \(|x|\ge a \iff x\le -a \ \text{or}\ x\ge a\).  
- \(|x-c|<r \iff c-r<x<c+r\) *(open interval of radius \(r\) centered at \(c\)).*  

# Worked Examples

::: {.callout-note title="ğŸ§® Example 1"}
Solve:
\[
|x| = 3
\]

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Solution"}
By definition:  
- If \(x\ge0\), then \(|x|=x=3 \Rightarrow x=3\).  
- If \(x<0\), then \(|x|=-x=3 \Rightarrow x=-3\).  

âœ… **Solution:** \(\{-3,3\}\).
:::
:::

---

::: {.callout-note title="ğŸ§® Example 2"}
Solve:
\[
|x-2| < 5
\]

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Solution"}
\(|x-2|<5 \iff -5 < x-2 < 5 \iff -3 < x < 7\).  

âœ… **Solution:** \((-3,7)\).
:::
:::

# Absolute-Value Inequalities

::: {.callout-note title="ğŸ“– Definition"}
An **absolute-value inequality** is an inequality involving absolute value, such as
\[
|f(x)| \ \{<, \le, >, \ge\}\ a,
\]
with \(a\ge0\). The solution uses the piecewise definition of the modulus.
:::

---

## ğŸ” Case breakdown (with \(a\ge0\))

- **Case 1 â€” less than**  
  \[
  |f(x)|<a \iff -a<f(x)<a.
  \]

- **Case 2 â€” less than or equal**  
  \[
  |f(x)|\le a \iff -a\le f(x)\le a.
  \]

- **Case 3 â€” greater than**  
  \[
  |f(x)|>a \iff f(x)<-a \ \ \text{or}\ \ f(x)>a.
  \]

- **Case 4 â€” greater than or equal**  
  \[
  |f(x)|\ge a \iff f(x)\le -a \ \ \text{or}\ \ f(x)\ge a.
  \]

::: {.callout-tip title="ğŸš§ Edge cases with \(a=0\)"}
- \(|f(x)|<0\): **no solution**.  
- \(|f(x)|\le0\): **equivalent to** \(f(x)=0\).  
- \(|f(x)|>0\): **equivalent to** \(f(x)\ne0\).  
- \(|f(x)|\ge0\): **always true** (for all \(x\)).
:::

---

## ğŸ¯ Centered forms
For \(|x-c| \ \{<,\le,>,\ge\}\ r\) with \(r\ge0\):

- \(|x-c|<r \iff c-r<x<c+r\)  *(open interval)*  
- \(|x-c|\le r \iff c-r\le x\le c+r\)  *(closed interval)*  
- \(|x-c|>r \iff x<c-r \ \text{or}\ x>c+r\) *(outside the interval)*  
- \(|x-c|\ge r \iff x\le c-r \ \text{or}\ x\ge c+r\)

---

## âš™ï¸ Micro-examples

- \(|x-2|<5 \iff -5<x-2<5 \iff -3<x<7\).  
- \(|2x+1|\ge3 \iff 2x+1\le-3\ \text{or}\ 2x+1\ge3 \iff x\le-2\ \text{or}\ x\ge1\).

# Practice Exercises

::: {.callout-note title="ğŸ“ Exercises"}
1. Solve: \(|x+1|\le4\).  
2. Solve: \(|2x-3|>5\).  
3. Solve: \(|x^2-1|<3\).  
4. Check whether \(|x+y|\le |x|+|y|\) for \(x=2, y=-5\).  
:::

::: {.callout-important collapse=true title="âœ… Answer Key"}
1. \(-4\le x+1\le4 \Rightarrow -5\le x\le3\).  
2. \(|2x-3|>5 \Rightarrow 2x-3>5\) or \(2x-3<-5\) â‡’ \(x>4\) or \(x<-1\).  
3. \(|x^2-1|<3 \Rightarrow -3<x^2-1<3 \Rightarrow -2<x^2<4\). Since \(x^2\ge0\), we get \(0\le x^2<4 \Rightarrow -2<x<2\).  
4. \(|2+(-5)|=|-3|=3\) and \(|2|+|{-5}|=2+5=7\). Indeed, \(3\le7\).  
:::
